Andrea Goethals wrote:
> Hello,
> 
> I did a host scope crawl with max-trans-hops set to 1. I thought that would 
> set a max to the number of non-L hops at the end of a discovery path.
> I am still seeing in the crawl log entries with many Xs on the end of their 
> discovery path like this one:
> 
> 2006-01-12T22:00:09.050Z   200       5842 
> http://www.deas.harvard.edu/projects/weitzlab/cgi-bin/webcal/webcal.cgi?function=addform&date=19950413&cal=Bohlin+Rheometer 
> LLLLLXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX 
> http://www.deas.harvard.edu/projects/weitzlab/cgi-bin/webcal/webcal.cgi?function=webday&date=19950413&cal=Bohlin%20Rheometer 
> text/html #026 20060112220008523+523 EXF54S6J3GGVMPONEIZBAUB4DYFPBQL7 -
> 
> Yes, a web calendar...
> I was thinking that if I could control the number of Xs on the end of the 
> discovery path then I could get it to filter out these type of things 
> automatically.

By default, 'trans' (for either 'transitive' or 'transclusion') hops can cause
URLs to be included, but not excluded. That is, one or more trans-hops which
lead *off* the site of main interest may still be retrieved -- in order to
be able to render the source page.

But no matter how many trans-hops, an URL which would have been included
anyway (ignoring the trans-hops dimension) won't be excluded. (In Heritrix
1.4 and prior, too many trans-hops *could* exclude an URL and wanted
on-domain material was occasionally being missed, so the behavior was
changed.)

If you wanted to have very fine-grained control over what hops-paths
are acceptable, and can use DecidingScope, there's a DecideRule called
HopsPathMatchesRegExpDecideRule which can ACCEPT or REJECT URLs based
on whether their hops-path matches a given regex. So for example, if
you wanted to REJECT all URLs that have more than 3 X's at the end of
the hops-path, you could configure this rule with a ".*X{3,}$" expression.

More generally, we most often prune calendar paths by watching crawls
and adding filters when they are noticed, but would love to assemble a
standard set of tunable heuristics into a code module for inclusion in the
crawler.

Hope this helps,

- Gordon @ IA
